title: RS22623
content: The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) administers retirement, survivors, disability, unemployment, and sickness benefits for railroad workers and their families. Workers covered by the RRB system include those employed by railroads engaged in interstate commerce. The RRB system is separate from Social Security but closely coordinated. Insured railroad workers receive RRB annuities instead of Social Security benefits. To qualify for an RRB annuity, a worker must generally have at least 10 years of covered railroad work. The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) administers retirement benefits for railroad workers. RRB annuities are paid instead of Social Security benefits if they are equal to or greater. There are two components: tier I, equivalent to Social Security benefits, and tier II, additional to tier I and based on covered railroad service. Tier I amounts increase annually with a cost-of-living adjustment. The Railroad Retirement Board (RRB) administers retirement benefits for railroad workers, including tier I and tier II annuities. Tier II amounts increase annually by 32.5% of the Social Security COLA. Surviving spouses of railroad workers may be eligible for RRB survivor annuities, which are generally higher than Social Security benefits. Widows and widowers can receive up to 100% of the worker's RRB annuity at full retirement age, with reduced annuities available as early as age 60. An annuity of up to 75% of the worker's tier I amount plus 100% of the worker's tier is available for a widow(er) caring for a deceased worker's child under age 16. The Railroad Retirement and Survivors' Improvement Act of 2001 (P.L. 107-90) increased initial annuities for qualifying railroad employees' widows(er)s. Other provisions in the law include investment flexibility, removing early retirement reduction for employees with 30 years of experience, reducing vesting years for tier II annuities, repealing annuity limitations, and changing the tier II tax structure. These changes apply to all widows(er)s receiving annuities. The 2001 law increased initial annuities for qualifying widow(er)s of railroad employees, with new rules applying to those receiving annuities from February 2002 onwards. A new guaranty amount was added, raising initial annuities for some widow(er)s. The total initial minimum amount under the current law is 100%. The 2001 law increased initial annuities for qualifying widow(er)s of railroad employees. The widow(er)'s annuity components change over time, with tier I and tier II amounts increasing annually. However, the total monthly annuity remains constant for several years due to offsetting COLA increases and guaranty reductions. The widow(er)'s annuity remains constant in nominal terms but decreases in real terms due to inflation. Once the guaranty amount reaches zero, the total monthly annuity increases for the first time, with tier I and tier II annuities continuing to rise annually. Under the 2001 law, widow(er)s receive higher annuities compared to prior law. In 2005, the average aged widow(er) annuity awarded was $1,416 per month, up from $1,138 in 2001. Under current law, a widow who has reached full retirement age and whose husband died in 2006 would receive an initial minimum amount of $1,300 per month. This includes a regular tier II amount of $150 and a guaranty amount of $150. The total annuity amount is $150 more than what she would have received under prior law. The annuity will not increase due to COLAs until her tier I and regular tier II amounts exceed her initial minimum. The widow's total annuity of $1,300 would not increase between 2006 and 2012 due to COLAs. However, her tier I and regular tier II amounts would change each year. In 2007, her tier I amount would increase by $23 and her regular tier II amount by $1. Despite not receiving a COLA, her total tier II annuity in 2007 would be $277, which is greater than what she would have received under prior law. The widow's annuity would increase starting in 2012 due to COLAs, with her total monthly amount under current law being $1,323, higher than the $1,300 in 2011. This increase would offset the gradual reduction of her guaranty amount to zero. The widow's annuity in 2012 and beyond would be the same under both current and prior law, with no difference in the monthly amount. Under prior law, the widow's monthly annuity in 2006 would have been $1,150, consisting of tier I ($1,000) and tier II ($150). However, under current law, she also receives a guaranty amount of $150, bringing her total annuity to $1,300 in 2006. The guaranty amount decreases annually as tier I and tier II amounts increase.
